docs.lead_paragraph: HCC Insurance Holdings Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Kachler Corporation, a privately held insurance agency, for $32.5 million in stock. HCC, based in Houston, is a specialty-insurance concern. Kachler, also based in Houston, specializes in life, accident and health insurance for large commercial customers.
docs.abstract: HCC Insurance Holdings to buy Kachler Corp, privately-held agency, for $32.5 million in stock (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Gov. George E. Pataki plans to use a one-time cash subsidy to keep down health insurance costs for some of New York State's sickest people (front page, Feb. 16). The cash subsidy should also be used to include the permanently disabled on Social Security who are under 65 years old in the Elderly Pharmaceutical Insurance Company prescription drug plan.
docs.abstract: S Ted Antholis letter on Gov George Pataki's plan to use one-time cash subsidy to keep down health insurance costs for some of New York's sickest people; says subsidy should be used to include disabled Social Security recipients who are under age 65 in special drug program (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-5 U.N. Team Discounts Sites As Annan Lands in Baghdad United Nations experts issued a report in Baghdad that portrayed the Iraqi sites off-limits to weapons inspectors as less threatening than Washington and the disarmament inspectors had indicated. American officials said the report was irrelevant. Secretary General Kofi Annan arrived in Baghdad for talks with Iraqi leaders that were seen as the last chance to avoid an American military strike. A4

docs.lead_paragraph: He came of age in the French Revolution. In the spirit of the times, he greatly admired Benjamin Franklin and Thomas Jefferson. And when the Bourbons managed to get their throne back in 1814, a discouraged Jean-Baptiste Say almost emigrated to America. He even wrote to Jefferson, asking how much he would have to pay to purchase a working cotton farm near Jefferson's own Virginia spread. ''I specify the neighborhood of Charlottesville,'' Say wrote from his home in Paris, ''because it is neither so close to the seaports to make the land too expensive, nor so distant as to present the rigors of a new settlement.''

headline.main: The Accidental Inventor of Today's Capitalism; Jean-Baptiste Say, No Longer a Villain, Stands Guard Over Free Markets

docs.abstract: Louis Uchitelle profiles 19th century French economics philosopher Jean-Baptiste Say, whose most famous 'law' can be summarized 'supply creates its own demand'; his hands-off, free-market theories of capitalism have become influential again; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton took action today to improve the quality of health care provided to more than 85 million Americans who participate in Medicare, Medicaid and various health insurance programs for Federal employees, retirees and veterans. Mr. Clinton ordered members of his Cabinet to enforce a ''bill of rights'' for patients who receive medical care through Government programs. Patients would be entitled to appeal denials of care or coverage by insurance companies, would get detailed information about the performance of their doctors and hospitals, and would generally have better access to medical specialists and emergency care.

headline.main: Clinton Orders Rights Action In Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: The withered heart of this once proud Yankee mill town tells the story of Representative Nancy L. Johnson's political troubles. A red Stanley Works sign shines brightly into the city sky, but a tool factory below has been dark for years. A battleship-size lot is all that remains of a bearing plant that once employed thousands. Even the few living factories are shadows of their former selves, the desolate streets and shuttered buildings nearby as forlorn as a Hopper painting.

headline.main: A District Good Times Forgot; Once Invincible, Connecticut Congresswoman Faces Tough Fight

docs.abstract: Rep Nancy L Johnson, eight-term Republican, is running for re-election in Connecticut's Sixth Congressional District; region's inability to pull out of its long, slow tailspin while nation's economy continues to soar has made Johnson, once considered among state's most durable and popular politicians, endangered incumbent; Bristol businessman Jim Griffin, Charlotte Koskoff, lawyer who was narrowly defeated by Johnson in 1996, and State Rep Demetrios Giannaros are seeking Democratic nomination; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Penncorp Financial Group of Manhattan said yesterday that it is negotiating a management-led buyout of two of its insurance subsidiaries. The company said it is discussing the buyout with executives of its Pennsylvania Life Insurance Company and Union Bankers Insurance Company units.

headline.main: Metro Business; Penncorp in Buyout Talks

docs.lead_paragraph: Foundation Health Systems Inc. said today that it planned to sell its workers' compensation insurance unit and had hired Salomon Smith Barney, a unit of the Travelers Group, as financial adviser for the sale. Foundation Health, a managed health care company, said it had decided to sell after reviewing recent ''negative'' developments at the insurance unit. In particular, the company cited substantial changes in the workers' compensation claims market in California.

headline.main: Foundation Health Systems Will Sell an Insurance Subsidiary

docs.lead_paragraph: John Calipari was guiding his team on a tour through the Nets' new practice facility today, and the players, seeing the state-of-the-art facility for the first time, were suitably impressed by the palatial locker room and the new court. Kendall Gill, who has endured practice sessions at the team's old haunts like the APA Trucking Recreation Center in North Bergen, where he would compete with off-duty truck drivers for court time and locker-room space, was enjoying the tour, at least until Sherman Douglas sidled up to him.

headline.main: Nets' New Practice Facility Befits a First-Class Team

docs.abstract: New Jersey Nets take tour of their new practice facility in East Rutherford that is expected to be completed in next two months (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Using tactics that were unheard of a few years ago, the pharmaceutical industry is increasingly marketing mental health drugs directly to consumers. In a break with past practice, which was simply to advertise in medical magazines and buttonhole doctors, manufacturers of antidepressants began advertising in general-interest magazines last year. And several companies have promoted psychotherapeutic drugs to mental health patients and their families through the Internet and personalized direct mailings.

headline.main: Psychiatric Drugs Are Now Promoted Directly to Patients

docs.abstract: Pharmaceutical industry is increasingly marketing mental health drugs directly to consumers using tactics unheard of few years ago; is promoting psychotherapeutic drugs to mental health patients and their families through Internet and personalized direct mailings, breaking with past practice of simply advertising in medical magazines and buttonholing doctors; says new strategy provides information that helps patients overcome problems, noting they remain protected because only doctor can write prescription; critics say patients influenced by marketing programs may seek out doctors willing to prescribe drugs not right for them; some doctors and patient advocates say those with certain mental illnesses are much more susceptible to being manipulated than those with other medical problems and are especially vulnerable; marketing of mental health drugs to consumers, which surged in 1997, added to explosive growth of direct-to-consumer advertising of prescription drugs (M)
